children.subject: <md>61bl is very different from 61a. When I AI'd for the class, there was a significant lab component (hence the L). The typical format would be 1 hour of lecture followed by 1 hour of lab, where the students could get help in real time. If you don't see yourself needing any help from others, then you'd be fine</md>
probably staying up to date with the material? i took 61a last summer and i think they recommended the same thing but there was no problem with me doing everything asynch and out of Berkeley
thanks for the advice. as the lecture times would be really late for me, do you know whether the lectures will be recorded?

if this is for 70 then you can get away with just reading the notes and ignoring lectures, you have discussion sections anyways. They were recorded and put on gdrive last summer for 70 i would expect the same to be true for this summer though

ya np fwiw though i would take 70 in a full semester so you can really digest the material. On the other hand, 61b went annoyingly slow and i hated that it didn't have a lab-component to it/bigger projects like gitlet (as well as projects having a larger emphasis in my grade—I took it with Hug though lol). I would personally recommend taking cs61bl in the summer and taking cs70 with professor Rao in the fall, he's a great professor and very generous with curving the class. Also Hilfinger will likely restructure his class in the fall to be less like sp20 wrt grading bins

<md>If you are intended CS, I had recommend you take 70 over 61B. A lot of students (a lot on this Piazza itself) have said that 70 over the summer is much more manageable given the time you have to study for it. My roommate did it and he also said the same. CS61B over the summer might be a lot more rushed. Plus, Hilfinger is teaching in the Fall whose grading scheme weighs projects a lot more heavily than exams and if you think you can give the time to projects, I highly recommend taking it with him. His projects are very time-consuming, but you definitely gain a lot from it. </md>

history.content:
I am planning to take cs 61b over summer. I am an international student and will be outside the US till the fall semester (+11 time zone difference). So I would not be able to attend lectures synchronously (2-4am in my time zone). In the course website it is written that it is strongly recommended to attend the lectures synchronously but if it is not possible, the recordings will be posted afterwards.

I would like to know what would be the advantages of synchronous over asynchronous attendance of the lectures.

thanks!
history.subject: CS61BL
